findings.title: Unprotected approve function
findings.description: The approve() method overrides current allowance regardless of whether the spender already used it or not, so there is no way to increase or decrease allowance by a certain value atomically unless the token owner is a smart contract, not an account. This can be abused by a token receiver when they try to withdraw certain tokens from the sender's account.

findings.title: Unprotected increaseAllowance function
findings.description: The approve() method overrides current allowance regardless of whether the spender already used it or not, so there is no way to increase or decrease allowance by a certain value atomically unless the token owner is a smart contract, not an account. This can be abused by a token receiver when they try to withdraw certain tokens from the sender's account.

findings.title: Unprotected decreaseAllowance function
findings.description: The contract allows decreasing allowance without any protection or access control, potentially leading to unauthorized changes.

findings.title: Unprotected transferFrom function
findings.description: The approve() method overrides current allowance regardless of whether the spender already used it or not, so there is no way to increase or decrease allowance by a certain value atomically unless the token owner is a smart contract, not an account. This can be abused by a token receiver when they try to withdraw certain tokens from the sender's account.

findings.title: Unprotected permit function
findings.description: No description provided in the audit report.

findings.title: Unprotected swap function
findings.description: The swap functions (swapTokensForExactETH, swapExactTokensForETH, swapETHForExactTokens) are unprotected and can be exploited.

findings.title: Unprotected initialize function
findings.description: The contract's initialize function can be called by anyone, potentially leading to unauthorized access and manipulation of the contract's state.
